Definition: You will receive four sentences of a story written in natural language, and one last sentence (Sentence5). Your task is to output 'Yes' if the last sentence completes the rest of the story coherently, or 'No' if it does not.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Rick grew up in a troubled household. Sentence2: He never found good support in family, and turned to gangs. Sentence3: It wasn't long before Rick got shot in a robbery. Sentence4: The incident caused him to turn a new leaf. 
 Sentence5: He is happy now.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, the incident turned a new leaf to Rick's life; so, he must be happy now.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Laverne needs to prepare something for her friend's party. Sentence2: She decides to bake a batch of brownies. Sentence3: She chooses a recipe and follows it closely. Sentence4: Laverne tests one of the brownies to make sure it is delicious. 
 Sentence5: Laverne doesn't go to her friend's party.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in the third sentence, Laverne follows the recipe closely; brownies should be delicious and she should not cancel going to her friend's party.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Sarah had been dreaming of visiting Europe for years. Sentence2: She had finally saved enough for the trip. Sentence3: She landed in Spain and traveled east across the continent. Sentence4: She didn't like how different everything was. 
 Sentence5 Sarah then decided to move to Europe.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, Sarah didn't like that everything was different; Sarah cannot decide to move to Europe.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Rick grew up in a troubled household. Sentence2: He never found good support in family, and turned to gangs. Sentence3: It wasn't long before Rick got shot in a robbery. Sentence4: The incident caused him to turn a new leaf. 
 Sentence5: He is happy now.
Negative Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, the incident turned a new leaf to Rick's life; so, he must be happy now. So, output should be Yes because Sentencce5 properly ends the story

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Laverne needs to prepare something for her friend's party. Sentence2: She decides to bake a batch of brownies. Sentence3: She chooses a recipe and follows it closely. Sentence4: Laverne tests one of the brownies to make sure it is delicious. 
 Sentence5: Laverne doesn't go to her friend's party.
Negative Examples.explanation: The answer can only be Yes or No.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Sarah had been dreaming of visiting Europe for years. Sentence2: She had finally saved enough for the trip. Sentence3: She landed in Spain and traveled east across the continent. Sentence4: She didn't like how different everything was. 
 Sentence5 Sarah then decided to move to Europe.
Negative Examples.output: Answer can be Sarah returned to the home.
Negative Examples.explanation: The answer can only be Yes or No.

Instances.input:
Sentence1: Oscar never made his bed. Sentence2: His mom always wanted him to. Sentence3: Finally he decided to start making his bed. Sentence4: His mom was proud. 
 Sentence5: She gave him a dessert treat.

Sentence1: Ben was late for class. Sentence2: His teacher yelled at him. Sentence3: He came in late the next day. Sentence4: His teacher wrote a note to his parents. 
 Sentence5: Ben crushes his alarm clock and buys a chicken.

Sentence1: Sara had lost her cat. Sentence2: She was so sad! Sentence3: She put up signs all over the neighborhood. Sentence4: Then a wonderful thing happened. 
 Sentence5: Somebody found her cat.

Sentence1: They had to pick out a stove for their new house. Sentence2: They couldn't decide on a particular brand. Sentence3: They liked the durability of the Viking. Sentence4: They also liked the deal with the Thermador. 
 Sentence5: They decided to buy the Viking stove.

Sentence1: Connie's doctor says she is overweight. Sentence2: She recommended better diet and exercise. Sentence3: One day, Connie joined a gym. Sentence4: The next day, Connie was disappointed to not see change. 
 Sentence5: She was proud of her body.

Sentence1: Lina went to see how candy canes were made. Sentence2: She watched as the workers added dye to the hot candy. Sentence3: Then, they stretched it out to make it shiny. Sentence4: Finally, they shaped it into a cane and let it cool. 
 Sentence5: Lina felt a new appreciation for candy canes.

Sentence1: Jessica was getting ready to graduate from college. Sentence2: She worked very hard in school and thought she deserved a reward. Sentence3: Her father knew that Jessica wanted a vacation. Sentence4: On her graduation day, Jessica's father surprised her with tickets. 
 Sentence5: Jessica was very angry with her dad.

Sentence1: Sheryl worked as a museum curator. Sentence2: Her family told her she worked a boring job. Sentence3: She tried to tell them that she got to work with living history. Sentence4: She tried to tell that their office jobs were a whole lot worse. 
 Sentence5: Sheryl was proud of her job as a museum curator.
